notes.comment: This 5-day hands-on workshop will teach you everything you need to build full-stack Kotlin applications. This is an in-depth coverage of the Kotlin programming language, the Kotlin standard library and the surrounding technologies. We cover all 4 of Kotlin's target platforms: JVM, browser, Android and native.

The list below reflects the *topics* covered but not the *order* or flow of the workshop.
          The flow of the workshop is like this: we build applications, and through this process,
          we cover the various features of Kotlin as they naturally arise.

content: Standard lib restrictions and extensions for JavaScript
Setting up the native build system
Building and running the sample apps
Using *reified* to access types at runtime
Function programming with complex data structures
Converting an OO app to functional
Returning two values from a function

notes.comment: In this workshop we build a non-trivial project over the course of the week. Much of this work is in the form of "do on your own" exercises. Through this technique, we cover the depth and breadth of Kotlin and related topics as they naturally arise in the context of building this project.
By the end of this workshop you will have built a modestly complex, full-stack Kotlin application with a Kotlin JVM back-end and two Kotlin front-ends: browser and Android.

Our public workshops have a maximum student count of 4. So each student is ensured an individualized training experience. We encourage you to bring in your projects and any special topics you'd like to cover.
A basic, but not advanced, knowledge of a Java-ish language (Java, JavaScript, etc.)
What are the defining features of Kotlin. Where does Kotlin fit into the broader landscape. What makes Kotlin special and why might Kotlin become the next big language.
He we master the nuts and bolts of the language. Types, ranges, functions, null-handling, control structures, string handling, error handling, etc.

The key to being productive with Kotlin is mastering the standard library. As a bonus, studying this library and it's idioms will also make you a better programmer. Here we cover the aspects of the library that I find most useful.

Kotlin is a powerful functional programming language. 80% of "Thinking in Kotlin" is "Thinking Functional". Functional concepts can be a big paradigm shift. We introduce these concepts here and continue to reinforce them throughout the workshop. In this section, we take an objected-oriented project created earlier and refactor it into purely functional app.

Here we learn how to build and deploy apps for all 4 of Kotlin's target platforms: JVM, Android, Browser and Native. We also learn how to create multi-platform modules so we can share code between the various tiers of our app.
Here you will learn how to build and automate your Kotlin projects using the most popular build tools from the Kotlin ecosystem.
This is about *idiomatic Kotlin*, i.e. doing things the Kotlin way. Here and throughout the workshop, we'll encourage idioms and practices that take best possible advantage of Kotlin's strengths.

One of Kotlin's major selling points is the IDE support. Kotlin is designed by an IDE company. The Kotlin language + the JetBrains IDE is a super productive combination. But we often find developers use only a fraction of the IDE's power. Learning the ins and outs of the IDE will be one of the most valuable things you'll learn in this workshop.

Kotlin is not crippled by the newness of the Kotlin ecosystem. This is because Kotlin takes maximum advantage of the platform via first-class interop and integration, be it Java, JavaScript or native. Here will learn how to migrate legacy apps to Kotlin and how to integrate with legacy code and 3rd party libraries.
Techniques and best practices for unit testing in Kotlin.
Advanced topics like reflection, creating DSLs, infix notation, inline functions, tail recursion, etc.
